somnus_collection.desc_o: head of ram left; below, bird standing left.
somnus_collection.desc_r: Incuse square.
somnus_collection.reference: SNG Arikantürk-; SNG Ashmolean-; SNG Copenhagen-; Klein-312.
somnus_collection.vendor_grading_notes: Good Very Fine; underlying lustre, attractive example of a very rare type.
somnus_collection.flavour_text: The incuse punch on the reverse was an early minting technique to try and combat forgeries. The idea was that you could see into the coin to see it is silver all the way through. This worked, until the forgers learned the art of plating.

somnus_collection.desc_o: Head of Athena right, wearing Corinthian helmet
somnus_collection.desc_r: prow of galley right, BA above, monogram below
somnus_collection.notes: Mint might actually be in Cyprus?

somnus_collection.desc_o: Helmeted head of Roma to right; X (mark of value) below chin, ROMA downwards behind, LABEO upwards before.
somnus_collection.desc_r: Jupiter driving galloping quadriga right, holding reins and sceptre and throwing thunderbolt; prow of galley below, Q•FABI in exergue.

somnus_collection.desc_o: Helmeted head of Roma right; mark of value behind.
somnus_collection.desc_r: Jupiter in quadriga to right, holding reins and sceptre and hurling thunderbolt; CARB below, ROMA in exergue.
somnus_collection.vendor_grading_notes: About Good Very Fine; very faintly burnished.
somnus_collection.flavour_text: Gnaeus Papirius Carbo "the younger" was consul in 113 BCE. At the time of this coins minting he was the moneyer who oversaw the mint, as he made his way along the cursus honorum. His father Gaius Papirius Carbo "the elder" was consul before him in 120 BCE, introduced laws extending the secret ballot and was aligned closely with Gaius Gracchus reformists. He was flipped to the Optimates however, even providing a legal defense for the murderer of Gaius Gracchus, with the consulship part of the reward. It didn't work out for him though - after proposing a law as consul to allow in indefinite re-election of Tribunes he was accused of undermining the state (by Lucius Licinius Crassus) in an oratory so strong that he killed himself to avoid conviction. By the time "the younger" became consul in 113 BCE the family name was still somewhat politically tainted but the Grachhan era was clearly over. After being assigned to a campaign in Cisalpine Gaul to defend against the invading Cimbri - a campaign that included defeat at the battle of Noreia - he was accused of incompetence/treason and like his father, committed suicide.

somnus_collection.desc_r: Athena Nikephoros standing left; T monogram in inner left field, E (date) in exergue.
somnus_collection.vendor_grading_notes: About Good Very Fine; monogram erased to reverse

somnus_collection.desc_r: Concordia standing left, holding patera and double cornucopiae.
somnus_collection.notes_history: As caesar, before the Pius! Caesar 25 February to 10 July AD 138 (4 months and 13 days). Augustus AD 138–161, nearly 23 years
somnus_collection.flavour_text: Before the Pius! He was Caesar under Hadrian for only ~4 months. He was full Augustus for 23 years. This coin was minted while he was Caesar and before the senate granted him the agnomen (honorary nickname) 'Pius'. Pius roughly translates to 'good bloke' - the senate clearly liked him.

somnus_collection.desc_o: Draped bust right, bare-headed, hair waved and fastened in a bun on back of head.
somnus_collection.desc_r: Venus, draped, standing left, holding dove in right hand and sceptre in left hand.

somnus_collection.desc_o: Bust of Faustina the Younger, draped, hair elaborately waved in nearly vertical lines and fastened in a low chignon at back of head, down cheek, curls, right.
somnus_collection.desc_r: Diana, draped, standing front, head left, holding transverse lighted torch in both hands.
somnus_collection.flavour_text: Diana was the Roman goddess of the hunt, moon, and childbirth. Lucifera means 'light bearer. I like to think this coin was a divine appeal by Faustina and Marcus for successful childbirth, after losing one of the many children they lost to stillbirth. The appeal was successful in the end, with 5/13 (or maybe 14) kids making it to adulthood. Women of the time may have kept this as a talisman when pregnant.

somnus_collection.desc_o: Bust of Crispina, draped, hair waived and rolled at crown and knotted on back of head, right.
somnus_collection.desc_r: Venus, draped, seated left, holding Victory in extended right hand and sceptre in left hand, right.
somnus_collection.notes_history: Married Commodus in 178. Exiled to Capri in 191. Likely executed on order of her husband. A daughter of senator Gaius Bruttius Praesens.
somnus_collection.flavour_text:
More political pawn than political animal, spare a thought for poor Crispina who was married to a psychopath and in way over her head.
Married Commodus in 178. Exiled to Capri in 191.  A daughter of senator Gaius Bruttius Praesens.
somnus_collection.legend_r_translation: Venus the Fortunate, by decree of the Senate.

somnus_collection.desc_r: Minerva standing left, holding olive branch and shield set on ground; spear leaning against arm.
somnus_collection.reference: RIC IV-7 corr. BMCRE-95 (Wars of the Succession); RSC-48.
somnus_collection.notes_history: Caesar (under Severus): 193–195 CE. Self-declared Augustus: 195–197 CE
somnus_collection.flavour_text: Caesar (under Severus): 193–195 CE. Self-declared Augustus: 195–197 CE. Biggest Roman civil war battle ever.
somnus_collection.legend_r_translation: Minerva the Peace-bringer, (when) consul for the second time.

somnus_collection.legend_r: PM TR P XI COS III PP
somnus_collection.desc_r: Fortuna enthroned left, holding rudder and cornucopie
somnus_collection.flavour_text: Militaristic crazy eyes. Spiky beard. Set the coin-fashion for the next few emperors. The African Emperor did a 'hostile takeover' of the ROman Empire, replacing many (most even) key positions of power with Africans.
somnus_collection.legend_r_expanded: P(ontifex) M(aximus) TR(ibunicia) P(otestate) XI CO(n)S(ul) III P(ater) P(atriae)
somnus_collection.legend_r_translation: Chief Priest, holding tribunician power for the eleventh time, consul for the third time, father of the fatherland.

somnus_collection.desc_r: Hilaritas standing half-left, holding long palm and cornucopiae, two boys to either side.
somnus_collection.flavour_text: A flan crack from antiquity - fromJulia's eyes to the womb. The two children, Caracalla and Geta play together happily around the goddess Hilaritas. This would not last.  At a meeting that she organised to encourage them to settle their disputes (leave your swords at home boys and listen to your mother) she looked on in horror as their dispute was settled with one of them dead in her arms. A dark coin.

somnus_collection.desc_r: Genius standing left, sacrificing out of patera over lit altar and holding corn-ears.
somnus_collection.reference: RIC IV-59b; BMCRE-579 (Septimius and Caracalla); RSC-114.
somnus_collection.vendor_grading_notes: Good Very Fine; lovely light cabinet tone.
somnus_collection.flavour_text: The year that he later became Augustus (209-211).
somnus_collection.legend_r_translation: Chief Priest and Consul for the second time

somnus_collection.legend_r: P M TR P XVI COS IIII P P
somnus_collection.desc_r: Hercules standing facing, head left, holding branch and club with lion's skin.
somnus_collection.legend_o_translation: Emperor Antoninus Pius, the Conqueror of Britain.
somnus_collection.legend_r_expanded: P(ontifex) M(aximus) TR(ibunicia) P(otestate) XVI CO(n)S(ul) IIII P(ater) P(atriae)
somnus_collection.legend_r_translation: Chief Priest, holding tribunician power for the sixteenth time, consul for the fourth time, father of the fatherland.

somnus_collection.desc_r: Venus, naked to waist, standing left, holding apple and palm, resting on shield; at feet, left, Cupid.
somnus_collection.notes_history:
"Daughter of Praetorian Prefect Gaius Fulvius Plautianus, who was close with Septimius Severus and sought to position his daughter in the imperial family via marriage to Caracalla. “…and the wedding was celebrated with the greatest extravagance, as if for a king, and Plautianus bestowed a dowry of ten myriads of sesterces.”
- (Cassius Dio, Roman History 77.1)"
somnus_collection.flavour_text:
"Daughter of Praetorian Prefect Gaius Fulvius Plautianus, who was close with Septimius Severus and sought to position his daughter in the imperial family via marriage to Caracalla. “…and the wedding was celebrated with the greatest extravagance, as if for a king, and Plautianus bestowed a dowry of ten myriads of sesterces.”
- (Cassius Dio, Roman History 77.1)"

somnus_collection.desc_o: laureate and draped bust right, wearing 'horn'.
somnus_collection.desc_r: Emperor standing left, sacrificing over tripod with patera and holding branch; star in left field.
somnus_collection.vendor_grading_notes: Extremely Fine; clear lustrous fields, fantastic eye appeal.
somnus_collection.flavour_text: The 'horn' on the diadem was no mistake - it was an (offensive to contemporary Roman culture) religious symbol of the cult of the sun god Elagabal. Emperor Antoninus (nicknamed Elagabalus) was the high priest. His efforts to supplant the traditional Roman pantheon in the city included building a huge temple to Elagabal on the Palatine hill and making the senate participate in rituals. This did not go down well in the long run.
somnus_collection.legend_r_translation: The Highest Priest, the Revered One

somnus_collection.desc_o: Diademed and draped bust right, set on crescent.
somnus_collection.desc_r: Pietas standing left, holding acerrum and extending hand over lighted altar to left.
somnus_collection.provenance: ex The Euclidean Collection; ex Roma Numismatics Ltd, E-Sale 101 (13/10/2022), lot 1074
somnus_collection.vendor_grading_notes: About Extremely Fine; an eye-catching portrait resting on a pleasant cabinet tone.
somnus_collection.flavour_text: The Antoninianus was introduced with a silver content of 52-55, but it was alrady down to 43-45% for this coin just a few years later.

somnus_collection.desc_r: Concordia, draped, standing left, sacrificing out of patera over lighted altar and holding double cornucopiae; in right field, star.
somnus_collection.notes_history: Vestal Virgin and the second and fourth wife of Elagabalus.
somnus_collection.flavour_text: A Vestal Virgin - a chaste religious figure upon who's virginity rested the fate of the empire (it was believed), was taken by emperor Elagabalus as his second and (one year later) fourth wife. A massive scandal.

somnus_collection.desc_r: Felicitas, draped, seated left, holding caduceus in right hand and cornucopiae in left hand.
somnus_collection.notes_history: Second daughter of Julia Maesa. Mother of Severus Alexander. Served as Regent.
somnus_collection.flavour_text: Second daughter of Julia Maesa. Mother of Severus Alexander. Served as regent quite effectively.

somnus_collection.legend_r: P M TR P VII COS II P P
somnus_collection.desc_r: Mars in military dress, standing half right, holding reversed spear and resting hand on shield
somnus_collection.flavour_text: Became emperor at 13 and reigned for 13 years - albeit under the direction of a 'regency council' that was dominated by his mother and grandmother (Mamea and Maesa). It was a fairly stable reign that met a fairly unstable end, leading to the very unstable Crisis of the Third Century
somnus_collection.legend_r_expanded: P(ontifex) M(aximus) TR(ibunicia) P(otestate) VII CO(n)S(ul) II P(ater) P(atriae)
somnus_collection.legend_r_translation: Chief Priest, holding tribunician power for the seventh time, consul for the second time, father of the fatherland.

somnus_collection.desc_r: Pudicitia seated left, drawing veil over face and holding sceptre.

somnus_collection.desc_o: Laureate, draped and cuirassed bust right.
somnus_collection.desc_r: Fides standing left, holding military standard in each hand.
somnus_collection.vendor_grading_notes: About Extremely Fine; a brilliant obverse, with a reverse struck from slightly worn die.
somnus_collection.flavour_text: Fides was the goddess of faith, trust, and loyalty, especially in agreements and promises.

somnus_collection.desc_r: Liberalitas, draped, standing front, head left, holding abacus in right hand and cornucopiae in left hand.
somnus_collection.notes: The first coin I added to the shopping cart of my first coin order
somnus_collection.flavour_text: Libertalitas was the goddess (or personification) of the emperors generosity.
somnus_collection.legend_r_translation: The Emperor’s Second Distribution of Bounty
